posts.com: /gd/, what is the name of this old art style? I really like it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438322
Isn't that pinup?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438322
Depends on what aspect of it you want to focus on, lots of pinups use that style of painting but are usually more standalone rather than display ads...that said many pinups in that style were made for calendars given out as advertising.
"Cheesecake" is another term for that style that carries a bit less of a sexually provocative vibe.
Neither term excludes illustrations made with diffentvtechniques like airbrush or photography, what those examples and many similar magazine and other advertising illustrations of the mid 20th century have in common is that they're all painted using gouache which allows for a very broad range of effects from solid opaque to watercolor-like washes and has a characteristic look that can be at once almost photorealistic but also very dramatic and painterly...it's very versatile and good for quick output on paper board so became the main medium for that kind of color illustration work when color photography was still cost prohibitive for magazines and other ephemera.
Picrel really shows just how wide a range of illustrative styles it can do while still being one cohesive look.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438332
If you want to see a true master of that gouache painting blend of realism and artistic license check out J. Fredrick Smith, who did sexy pinups, advertisingcart that wasn't necessarily focused on women at all, and later became a major photographer who shot the first Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue cover in 1964.

https://www.illustrationhistory.org/artists/j.-frederick-smith

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438332
>photorealistic but also very dramatic and painterly..
That's what I like about it so much. It's so realistic but slightly "cartoony". Thanks for all that information. Is there really no official term for this art style? Seems odd since it was so popular and highly used for a decent period of time.

Smith's art is fantastic, wow, by the way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438336
>It's so realistic but slightly "cartoony"

Funny you mention that, "cartoon" originally meant something different than it does now and was essentially a sketching color rendition of a larger work like a fresco or tapestry, done on heavy paper using water based paints.
Picrel is a famous example and hints at that realistic style
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raphael_Cartoons
...compare that image to someone like Frank Frazetta who combined that old school technique with purely fictitious situations and subjects, and was also both a comic book artist and fine art painter who was a major influence in the illustration style of the latter half of the 20th century. Part of that was to use more posterized color pallettes (like comic books) combined with very realistic modeling and light depictions of the old masters.
In broad terms "fantasy realism" is one term that applies to this general style but many people see that as strictly being about "fantasy" like sword and sorcery or sci-fi related illustrations, largely because of people like Frazetta and Boris Vallejo.

But Frazetta also did straight up pinup art too, and even in his most medieval/Sci fi fantasy art there's usually a healthy dose of cheesecake sensibilities.
Boris is the same.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438337
Not quite as photorealistic as some of Smith's work, but very focused on realism anatomically and in the related play of light...along with being cartoonist at the same time.
The look is a bit different, Frazetta worked mostly in oils but he used gouache too, sometimes together.
He also tended to work a lot smaller than you'd imagine, some of his most epic and complex works are like 9"×12".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438341
>the important parts like faces are quite detailed/emphasized, yet less meaningful areas like clothes are depicted in this flat, graphic manner.

some of that goes back to the original cartoon as a map for a larger work concept where its basically a looser color sketch and only the detailed areas need to be finished out.
Its also a painter's approach where you do a minimal underpainting to block out color balance and hues, that is part of how they get that natural lighting effect where objects and materials almost glow and that glow all ties together across the color fields. IOW they develop the elements and shapes and light reflections on them out of that undetpainting rather than drawing them and adding a reflection on top afterwards.
For commerci illustrators leaving those backgrounds undeveloped saved time and printing hassle/costs but also helped focus on the important action, and became a style...its not for nothing that this is a common comic book technique too, for the same reasons. FWIW a lot of modern western artists got that from traditional Asian art, especially prints.

As for other artists, theres so many...lots of great illustrations were made so fast and in such quantity that nobody really knows who did them, just looking through old magazines is a treasure trove.
One major player worth checking out is Mort Künstler-
https://www.illustrationhistory.org/artists/mort-kunstler

Even with a monochromatic lighting scheme picrel manages a very convincing realism where it matters...it's more finished but when you look closely at the details away from the illuminated center action around her face and body, much of the detail is not that detailed at all and almost impressionistic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's image to image-to-image Stable diffusion or Dall-e.
You basically use an original input image (i.e lel happymerchant.jpg) give a prompt for you desired result (i.e a stack of cash) and generate.
You can adjust the denoise (how much is actually changed by the AI) lower or higher based on your desired result. You can also change how strong the AI interoperates the prompt, basically giving more or less freedom.

The monumental scale contrasted by the simplicity and brutalness of the plain concrete and untarnishable metal touch my soul in a way i can scarely describe. The interiors are also comfy; abandoned for millennia, yet still as beautiful and functional as the day they were constructed. Their soft glows of blue, gold, and occasional white. Their purpose unclear, but still comforting.

If i ever had the opportunity, i would have my house constructed in such a style, doubling as a library or orphanage after my death. To continue giving on its sterile beauty long after my own passing would be a gift far greater than any amount of money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>436731
>Is this normal to do in this line of work?

In general, manager/director types who are good manage problems, not people and direct the right people under them to do the work and let them do it, bad ones are always managing/directing for the sake of making it look like they are doing important work. There's an old saying that the best manager is the guy with his feet on his desk, he's done his job by delegating to the right people and only has to spring into action when things arent operating smoothly.

Revisions and fickle attitudes and mixed signals and all that are definitely part of GD work, you just have to take them in stride unless they are real deal breakers.
One thing you can do with preliminary ideas is to sort of guide the discussion by making some of the X number of ideas you are tasked with generating way out of the box as opposed to subtle variations on some limited scope someone says they *want*...

This has a number of benefits:
>if four of lets say ten ideas are tossed immediately that's 40% fewer designs they can argue and micromanage you over
> it asserts the idea that you aren't just a robot who can only interpret other people's ideas and that you are a creative asset
>it may cause people stuck in a rut to gain a new perspective from seeing something their requests were prejudiced against, that they subconsciously didn't want to see because they didnt want to have to make a choice if they liked it, admit they were wrong, not the best idea person, etc.
I agree that that one page looks like something on stationary or a wedding invitation except for the middle row LH one....it's not a modern take on laurels at all.

1/2

Personally I'd try taking a basic laurel or similar "award" motif and really distorting it to make it interesting but still recognizable, maybe reverse a silouette out of a circle or another geometric shape...and make a couple of reallly out there options.
If anyone bitches that those were nothing like they asked for, just sweetly mention that since there seemed to have been some previous issues with the choices presented that stuck more firmly to those criteria, in the interests of finding a solution you thought it might be helpful to offer some options that might help narrow down to a plan, since the original ideas that followed the more narrowly defined criteria didn't seem to work...of course you u derstand that they might not be accepted but knowing better what everyone doesn't want based on them actually seeing sonething might help break the logjam, since what they *said* they didn't want before turned out to be what they actually wanted.

Don't be snarky or a dick, just explain that that happens sometimes and thats why creative people toss out ideas that way in visual form, and you're here to help expedite the process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>436732
I mean, overall my art director is very helpful, but she was hired 6 months after I was and I felt her method of doing things kinda threw a wrench in our workflow.

Usually a project manager would assign a project. I’d create a proof with some designs, and the project manager would send the proof to the client and then return with their feedback. We usually upload a proof in a work management site where anyone can easily leave comments.

With this art director, she’ll ask for the tiniest revisions like “make this word 25% smaller”, or “move this block down a tiny bit”.

For one project, the client required a high-res photo of one of the hotel properties to be used as a hero image. All we needed to do was provide a photo from the company’s photo repository. Even after uploading the photo in the proof, the art director asked if I could “make the photo a bit brighter”.

The photo was of a bright beautiful beach scene already heavy edited. Since we were already at deadline, I felt this was an unnecessary change that would end up adding 15-30 minutes of time, just uploading the damn thing. I pushed back and said “this photo already seems bright enough already and we’re close to deadline. Let’s just submit what we have, and if the client feels it should he brighter, I’ll make the change”. She agreed, we sent it over, and what do you know? The client just liked the photo as is.

While I feel this art director is helpful, I feel she’s requesting the smallest of changes. Which would be fine if we were in the beginning stages, but she’ll ask for “a few more tiny revisions from me :)” when we’re at or past deadline.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>436758
Different anon here, but I recall nitpick details people gave me a hard time about, and I finally just had them sit down with me and just tell me exactly as they invisioned it. Literally pixel by pixel, I just let them say whatever came to mind, hardly offered any insight, and they hardly asked for it. The project was painful to do, and other clients wanted to do it this way also while trying to short my hours. I since left the field and am now in manufacturing. I didn't have the right conditions to flourish in the arts and sciences, but oh well, "World needs ditch diggers, too." - Caddyshack

Later, I learned it was not the art they wanted, but what the art facilitated: a feeling of value.

One day at a time, and you will be on track to lead these kinds of projects in bigger capacities. Good things are coming your way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>436754
That's the same clipart I used to make my example...it's very traditional and flat and just...there.
If a "modern" take is really the goal it's going to take something fairly radical to shake off that generic look.
I did it with forcing the perspective and making it an oval, the leaves at the top got compressed and would need more work on a real graphic but that effect does simplify how it reads because it still suggests the laurel but without large separate leaves...it's more impressionistic and less literal.
The oval shape also adds a twist on the generic one and i think is more streamlined without being too far out.
Not saying this is *the* solution, just offering ideas on getting away from the cliche one while still keeping the essence of it that makes it recognizable as an award seal.

As for the AD, it really sounds like someone not very sure of themselves trying to assert their place but not confident enough to really take charge and direct bold moves....hence a bunch of tiny tweaks. It's a good sign that you pushed back and she was reasonable about it, the end result was a happy client so use that to guide her in the future and you can probably minimize a lot of that kind of change for changes sake directive.
Learning how to read people and assert yourself with superiorsxand clients is a huge part of this kind of work, it takes diplomacy and confidence on your part as well. It's not always easy to blend the two and certain people and situations will require a different mix. It's sales in some respect, and sales tactics can help- you need to reassure people that you're there to help them get their needs met, want what's best for them, and you need to steer them towards resolutions by eliminating barriers they put up to accepting what you are selling.
1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>436774
2/2
That process might need to happen over an entire concept but it might also be necessary over a single leaf on a cheesy Clipart laurel branch. If you are passionate about what you feel is important and willing to compromise and accept constructive criticism you'll be fine and rather than being seen as ornery your willingness to push back will make you less of a target for nitpicking and hopefully will cause people choosing respect and value your willingness to fight for what you think is the best product.
Managers and clients may think they want a yes man or get mad when they get told no, but especially in this kind of field you really dont want a yes man, you want all contingencies addressed before you're in too deep and that's a huge part of what any design work involves.

>>438072
The rule of thumb for a book title, is the "glance" rule - it should be legible if glanced at on a shelf in a book store. Or, you can go in the opposite direction, and make the art what catches the eye. Yours is currently that. So, decide what you want to do.
I would a cleaner font, to offset the splash of confusion of the art - you're trying to get way too much information across with the art, it's jumbled and has it's own composition errors and style issues (why is everything the same line width?), but the title blurs into the art because it's too small, and too similar. You want contrast between the title, and the art. Decide which one is more important.

The font you're using is also really fucking hard to read, and the yellow drop shadow is ugly. You're trying too hard with this cover, across the board.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>438517
Because the basic typeface it resembles the Eurostile family (and its direct predecessor) and especially when it's extended people have been conditioned to think "futuristic" for over half a century-

"Eurostile is a popular font, particularly suitable for headings and signs. Its linear nature suggests modern architecture, with an appeal both technical and functional. The squarish shapes with their rounded corners evoke the appearance of television screens of the 1950s and 1960s. It is particularly popular in science fiction artwork and media set or produced in the 1960s and 70s, alongside other graphic design use. Eurostile and its antecedent Microgramma had a near-monopoly on science fiction typefaces through the end of the 20th century, before Ray Larabie, seeing an opening in the market, began designing more modern computer fonts for the genre and distributed them through freeware."

Top one in picrel is Eurostile Extended

posts.com: Creating a holiday themed flyer. How would one go about recreating this kind of hand-stitched crochet look in PS? Texture packs? Or specific layer styles?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>438525
first, thats not crochet, look up cross stitch and needlepoint fonts and youll findxall kinds of lettering and other elements.
That kind of work is based on a grid and is essentially pixellated so to start use a grid layer to establish the layout and size the type "sitching" to fit with it, and if you import any other graphics do the same, and maybe adjust the color depth down so that the pixellated color areas match too.
For other types of needlework like embroidery a line pattern that mimics the stich directions can be overlaid, and similarly a screen/mesh pattern that matches the main grid size can be added over graphic elements to accentuate the look of being made up of blocks, and any areas that don't follow that grid structure removed.

You’re going to be dealing with mostly the same concepts if you go from blender to another software for modeling, texturing, lighting, and rendering.

Blender is perfectly usable nowadays and has a lot of nice features out of the box. I would just learn it, I had to learn it two years ago for a new job as a 3D motion designer and now I’m back to doing regular design work and it’s been immensely helpful when it comes to creating my own mock-ups and compositions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>437215
First, you should know what other apps do. You listed Renderman, which is a rendering platform, not a 3D app. You can even use it with Blender, and it's free:https://rmanwiki.pixar.com/display/RFB24/RenderMan+for+Blender+24.0
It replaces Cycles.
Second, Blender does the same things as commercial software, but in different ways - mostly because they need to avoid lawsuits from companies like Autodesk, if the copy one of their patents. A lot of Maya users will say 'Oh, Blender does this too - just differently", so you'll be familiar with the concept, not the execution.
Most 3D artists get enough experience with most popular packages to get basic tasks done, and focus on one - like knowing Maya well enough to set up a scene, light it, and render it, but focus on modeling in zBrush.
Theres no downside to learning Blender. The commercial stuff has better high end things, but you probably don't have the computing power to use it, like render farms and such.
This guy made this video in 3 months in Blender:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GlFF4BsO10
But probably has years of effort learning to get there.
There's no downside to sticking with Blender, or learning other packages. zBrush is a powerful app, for instance. Rhino is better for organic shapes. 3DS is a top end modeling app. Maya is the best for animation. Blender tries to do a bit of what all of them do, but not as deep.

posts.com:
>>433069
>>433039
>As a general rule of thumb if you can't imagine it in your head, dall-e 2 can't either.
>keep it simple
All premised on a notion that there is some ideal response to these prompts that can be attained by tailoring them to what you think that ideal might look like.
Nothing wrong with that approach where it's appropriate but it's very heavily weighted towards an engineering/ problem solving approach that avoids the random surprise and unstructured expectation aspects of art that differentiate it.
IOW while both art and engineering/ design are derivative to some extent and require selection of goals and experimenting and vetting of results to see if they fit, the fact that AI can't really think or reason actually makes it well suited for an approach that treats overthinking as something to avoid.
That is to say that not helping it with streamlined instructions and deliberately confusing it with vague prompts and nonsensical or conflicting terms can yield great results too and the nature of computing means it isn't hampered by ego or fear of coming up with the "wrong" response.

Pic related: "Chuck Berry Breakfast Donkey" via Wombo Dream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>433093
Also fun to use non-visual and conflicting prompts to see just how inside-the-box AI responses are, like "silent hot loud antique" which Wombo obviously "creates" by combining some pretty on-the-nose tropes like big empty room for silent, fireplace for hot, a stereo for loud, and everything brown and/ or dusty for antique.
It's still kind of interesting but not that different from what a lazy and not too creative artist might render.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>433106
Yeah, I get that but a lot of the prompts people do come up with are so specific and all encompassing that there's no room for any novelty or surprises. They remind me of clients who come in with a laundry list of elements they want in some design that essentially leave no room for creativity and design.
They might as well just be clip art or photoshop; " I want a goat, and a car and a phone booth and a blimp at sunset with mountains" isn't hard at all to imagine or compose and the incongruity doesn't really serve any purpose when so little is left to interpret. You could literally use props to create that scene.
There's a fine line in between where you could get some interesting results but the ones in this thread are pretty mundane and unimpressive.
That was my only point, that stuff like this requires rethinking your entire approach to get anything that different than what that approach already allows, and the approaches I see are the source of boring results.
This also applies to the approach developers take to designing the processes, which is often nothing like how exciting art and design are created.

>>433380

Thanks for the clarification

>Additionally, if you look at other SOTA models like Parti, or Imagen, shorter texts are actually capabilities right now.

Again, not quite clear what you mean..."shorter texts" meaning it can accurately create what short combination/order of letters is asked of it , like IBM or USA or MSNBC?

Progress is progress, I guess but compared to what humans can do in this respect I still don't see where it is anything to fear as far as taking work from people, or will be at some point in the future.
As an approach to design/ composition it doesn't seem to offer any new or novel perspective and just mimics the way artists already do this, with large gaps in its ability to stretch beyond that built in boundary of "this is the process by which you achieve X", with X being some ideal design/composition.

Sure, lots of graphic design works that way but it can already be done with basic templates and formulas that don't require much intelligence at all to " create" with.
The more creative any designer is, the more he steps away from rigid protocols and formulas as the final arbiter of what to turn in, while holding to protocols that need to be adhered to like putting the correct letters in order in a logo design with no extras.
What I see is the exact opposite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>433496
>hypothetically what would you need to see from a text-to-image model to be convinced otherwise?

Honestly, some proof that there was some need for it or reason for trying to do it in the first place.
I do see some value in a tool that gets you out of old habits and scripts and have played around with some stuff online but more in the sense of trying to shake it loose from what it's "supposed" to do. That to me is the hurdle to any creative endeavor; scripts and formulas and recipes have their place but tweaking and re-imagining them is where the creative spirit manifests.
When it comes specifically to text, labels and the like that becomes less valuable and familiarity ie being able to interpret the text is crucial.
It doesn't really matter to me that these AI systems get mixed up on text, the point is why does anyone need AI to spell or lay out text in a graphic design based on someone's prompt to begin with?
It's dirt simple to begin with and what is the practical impetus for creating artificial " intelligence" to do it?
It's amazing and all but other than as a means of researching AI or selling the next great thing to people who care about that, I really don't see what advantage it has that would displace human designers any more than all the dumb methods like clip art and design templates and stencils and photography and their digital counterparts did before AI.
It's like self driving cars- there's a place for them but much of the hype around them is a solution looking for a problem.
People aren't clamoring for them because doing it the old fashioned way isn't that hard and they don't want to hand over total control to a machine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>433496
>I think you put these paragraphs very well.
Thanks, it's something I've given a lot of thought to when creating art/ design but also music that tries to avoid becoming stale and repetitious and predictable while remaining relatable. Musicians have been using computers and electronics to assist them for a long time, long enough for many cycles of novel approaches becoming trite and clichéd.
One cool tool that may seem off topic but imo really isnt is the Oblique Strategies card system that assists in breaking through blocks and rote approaches in human creators -

"Each card contains a gnomic suggestion, aphorism or remark which can be used to break a deadlock or dilemma situation. A few are specific to music composition; others are more general. For example:

Use an old idea.
State the problem in words as clearly as possible.
Only one element of each kind.
What would your closest friend do?
What to increase? What to reduce?
Are there sections? Consider transitions.
Try faking it!
Honour thy error as a hidden intention.
Ask your body.
Work at a different speed..."
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oblique_Strategies
Note that the second suggestion
>State the problem in words as clearly as possible
is essentially the basis for AI art programs...its a valid approach but it's only one approach and in that system it's no better or worse a suggestion than "ask your body".
Ultimately the human decides what works and what doesn't and the ability to make those determinations and benefit from even silly or inscrutable suggestions like "Think of the radio" is where AI can't compete.
1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>433509
2/2


One of the Oblique Strategies prompts I like a lot is "Ask people to work against their better judgement" and that kind of sums up how I approach all of this stuff, I want to see and hear raw material and concepts that aren't filtered and constrained and tempered by formula or reason or even intelligence, and then refine them as needed into completed works.

Anyway, here's an online version, imagine being able to get this stuff in an AI artist's head along with a prompt-

http://stoney.sb.org/eno/oblique.html

>>434332
>Do you have unlimited credits or something?
>How/why you doing this if it costs the moolah?
If you get accepted in their beta (and it's easier to be visited by Jessica Christ in a wet dream) you get 50 free credits and after that they'll give you 15 free credits per month. 4 image generations per credit, 3 image edits per credit, and 1 image enlargement per credit. If you were lucky enough to get in the beta early they'll reward your luckiness with an extra 100 credits.
But there's a thing, those 65 credits you get at the start vanish after a month whether you use them or not, so people could just fulfill requests when their credits are about to disappear, anyway.

posts.com: Why is /gd/ not as schizo and in full on cope mode with AI unlike /ic/? Especially considering fine and Trad artists are at far less risk of losing out to automation then graphic design a work piplines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>437406
good question.
since it is such a slow board my guess is that is has to do with users here on average being actually somewhat interested in gd instead of circle-shit-jerking like /ic/ is. ic is mainly a self congratulating shitshow of socially depraved dopamine junkies, if you ask me.

another reason could be that SD (and other machine learning systems) as it stands now isn't really all that great/trained for that purpose yet? it simply didn't have the chance to prove itself in that regard. I tried getting out some logo designs, and quality is far less consistent compared to other subjects, if you don't use custom weights.

or maybe designers as a species are more used to take advantage of current technological advancements instead of defining their own identity in not using obvious tools as 'crutches'. 'artists' take pride in feeling llike everyone thinks they are able to come up with all that shit on their own. So AI kinda is a threat to their whole existence. 'art'. 'design'. as identities they are not the same.

I am open to other ideas though! Id enjoy seeing some discussion actually.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>437408
last thought I want to add to this for now.

I think that to a large extend /ic/ is populated by 'losers' who feel like no one would want them.
I am not trying to be mean but instead do feel some degree of sympathy for them. yet my point is that if there isn't much economic or social value to your very own person, it seems like an obvious alternative to search for purpose and fullfillment in one of the lonelier arts.

In that case AI would be a much greater personal threat to the average /ic/ user.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>437409
There's actually now quite a few tuned models for creating icons, etc.
However more importantly is the ability to tune your own models, which I predict will make design pipelines SO MUCH more efficient.
Imagine this, you already have a good design and and layout for say box art on a product, but the client also wants the icons and the manuals to be the same style. Well with a tuned model that's as simple as directing a prompt from "icons" to "box" art and still retain 100% consistency.

anyway here's some working examples that you could probably experiment with, again bleeding edge so don't take it at face value.
https://publicprompts.art/app-icons-generator-v1-dreambooth-model/

You can train Stable diffusion models with dreambooth.

I've started using Adobe Illustrator for the last couple of days and holy shit, this program is made by autists. It's unnecessarily complex and there are way too many things while using the pen tool that just don't make sense and make the work process that many times slower. And the layout is way too cluttered and feels crowded.
On the contrary, Affinity Designer allows a clean layout, a ridiculously easy to use pen tool and things like having a plethora of geometric shapes that make the work process a lot easier and quicker to get down.

The only things that I see Affinity Designer lacking are the mesh tool and the shape builder, may even add the width tool and having multiple gradients in one object as well. The moment Serif adds those things to their program, Adobe Illustrator dies, fuck your Creative Cloud.

>>437554
How big of a scratch disk do you have for it? It needs it as much as Photoshop does.
You need at minimum a dedicated partition, on a seperate physical drive if HDD if possible, that's 3x the size of the biggest file you work on. And, reduce the undo and history levels. Then go into the typical settings you can use, like lowering the raster preview setting, reduce screen quality, reduce the number of installed fonts, etc.
